questions.text: In which of the following patients would you prefer to use an LMA for securing the airway?

choices.text: A term G2P1L1 woman previously diagnosed with pre-eclampsia planned for elective Cesarean section
A 30-year-old patient to be taken up for repair of hiatus hernia
A middle-aged man with a history of diabetes diagnosed with pharyngeal abscess
A 40-year-old woman planned for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, having Mallampatti class III airway

questions.solution:
Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is indicated in cases with difficult airway where endotracheal intubation is not possible or not available. It can be used as an alternative to an endotracheal tube for ventilating and oxygenating the patient. 

LMA is relatively contraindicated in conditions that are associated with increased risk of aspiration (e.g.: Hiatal hernia, pregnancy, inadequate NPO). LMA may protect the larynx from pharyngeal secretions but not from gastric secretions. The presence of a pharyngeal pathology such as an abscess or tumor, or a pharyngeal obstruction is also a relative contraindication of LMA insertion.

The normal anatomic position of the LMA.

The proximal portion of the LMA rests upon the epiglottis, whereas the distal end or, the tip extends into the pharynx at the upper end of the esophagus. The opening on the laryngeal mask overlies the laryngeal inlet.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Poor mouth opening 
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O.

questions.text:
You administer epidural anesthesia to a patient before surgery. Which of the following methods can you use to test the adequacy of motor block in him?
  1. Electromyography
  2. Train of four ratio
  3. Modified Bromage Scale
  4. Bispectral index
  5. Spirometry
questions.solution:
Electromyography, Modified Bromage scale, and spirometry can all be used to test the adequacy of the motor block after neuraxial anesthesia.

The Modified Bromage Scale is most commonly used, but the disadvantage is that this represents only lumbosacral motor fibers.

Modified Bromage scale

0: No motor block

1: Inability to raise extended leg; Able to move knees and feet

2: Inability to raise extended leg and move knee; Able to move feet

3: Complete block of motor limb

Electromyography and pulmonary function tests (spirometry) have been used to measure abdominal and thoracic motor function, but these are neither practical nor specific.

Train of four ratio and bispectral index are used in monitoring a patient under general anesthesia.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl child is scheduled for a tonsillectomy. Prior to endotracheal intubation, she is given IV propofol, followed by an agent, labeled "A" as shown below. The procedure is completed as planned and the anesthetist now administered a new drug (a gamma-cyclodextrin), labeled "B" in the image to reverse its effect. Read the statements given below and choose the correct statements.
  1. "A" is a non-depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant
  2. "B" is excreted unchanged in the urine complexed with the blocking agent used
  3. "A" is a depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant
  4. The order of affinity of "B" for "A" is  - rocuronium, vecuronium, and pancuronium
  5. The order of affinity of "B" for "A" is  - succinylcholine, pancuronium, and vecuronium
  6. "B" has no effect on atracurium
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a non-depolarizing agent, rocuronium (labeled "A" in the image) is used for induction prior to endotracheal intubation. Following the surgical procedure, a newer drug, gamma-cyclodextrin ("B" in the image), sugammadex is used to reverse its action.

Sugammadex has the most affinity for rocuronium and has no effect on succinylcholine and benzylisoquinoline NMBAs such as atracurium. 

The graph shows the train-of-four monitoring to assess the neuromuscular block in an anesthetized patient. The fade in the graph indicates non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent which is reversed by sugammadex. 

Sugammadex is a novel reversal agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.

Sugammadex is a modified gamma-cyclodextrin that binds rocuronium and vecuronium tightly and decreases the concentration of free plasma levels.

A specific reversal agent for rocuronium, i.e., sugammadex can terminate the action of rocuronium.

Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It exerts its reversal effect by forming tight complexes in a 1:1 ratio with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium > vecuronium >> pancuronium).Since rocuronium is a steroidal agent, it is specifically bound by sugammadex.

Sugammadex is essentially eliminated unchanged via the kidneys.

Rocuronium at a dose of 0.6 mg/ kg intravenously is commonly used to provide muscle relaxation during routine intubation in pediatric patients because of its faster onset and it can be administered intramuscularly. For rapid sequence induction, a higher dose (0.9-1.2 mg/kg) can be used.

A disadvantage with rocuronium is its long duration of action and the possibility of hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: During surgery, the anesthetist notices the soda lime is nearly exhausted. And hence asks for it to be replaced with an amsorb CO2 absorber from the nearby OT. Which one of the following options represents the contents present in this new CO2 absorber?
questions.solution:
Amsorb is a CO2 absorbent used in rebreathing system consisting of calcium hydroxide, calcium chloride (CaCl2), calcium sulfate (CaSO4), and polyvinylpyrrolidone added to increase hardness.

Advantage: It is more inert than soda-lime and baralyme and so associated with lesser degradation of anesthetics and so less carbon monoxide production.

Related Pearl: Composition of CO2 Absorbers in rebreathing system

SODA LIME:

  • Ca(OH)2 - 80%
  • NaOH - 3%
  • KOH - 2%
  • Silica - 0.2%
  • Moisture-  14-19%

Granule size is 4-8 mesh

Absorbs up to 23L of CO2/100 g

With Trilene, soda-lime forms neurotoxin dichloroacetylene and pulmonary irritant phosgene gas; hence contraindicated.

Sevoflurane reacts with soda lime and produces Compound A

Method of hardness- Silica

  • Ca(OH)2
  • Ca Cl2

Causes less degradation of volatile anesthetics eg. Sevoflurane to Compound A or Desflurane to Carbon Monoxide

  • Ca(OH)2 80%
  • Ba(OH)2 20%
  • KOH <1%

Absorbs up to 9-18L of CO2/100 g

Desflurane can be broken down to CO by dry barium hydroxide lime.

Method of hardness: water of crystallization.

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Miller laryngoscopic blade. 

A laryngoscope is an instrument used for examination of the larynx and facilitation of tracheal intubation. It has three components: the handle, the blade, and the light source. The Macintosh and Miller blades are the most popularly used blades.

Miller's blade is a straight blade. Its curve begins 2 inches from the tip. It is inserted using the para-glossal technique. This technique avoids contact with the maxillary incisors and provides maximal tongue control.

It is used in:

  • Neonates, infants, and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Macintosh blade is a sharply curved blade with a large flange. It is inserted in the right side of the mouth, and the flange is used to sweep the tongue to the left. The blade is advanced and positioned in the vallecula. Advantages of a curved blade include:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: A woman underwent transvaginal cerclage under general anesthesia. Propofol was used for induction and succinylcholine was used for anesthesia maintenance. Even after 6 hours after the procedure, there were no signs of neuromuscular function recovery. Later, her dibucaine number was found to be 20. Identify the enzyme defect for the given condition.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of delayed recovery from a neuromuscular blockade by succinylcholine with dibucaine number 20, the defect is in the butyrylcholinesterase (pseudocholinesterase) enzyme. Dibucaine number 20 is seen in people with homozygous atypical butyrylcholinesterase which prolongs the action of succinylcholine to 4-8 hours. 

Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity. Dibucaine is a local anesthetic that inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by 80% but inhibits heterozygous atypical enzyme activity by 40-60% and homozygous atypical enzyme activity by only 20%. Accordingly, the patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80, and the patients with atypical pseudocholinesterase will have a lesser dibucaine number.

Succinylcholine and mivacurium are metabolized by the enzyme pseudocholinesterase. Some conditions like liver disease, pregnancy, advanced age, renal failure, major burns, and oral contraceptives might lead to the minimal prolongation of neuromuscular paralysis.

People with atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme will have reduced clearance of succinylcholine and mivacurium over time, thus prolonging the recovery time. Patients with one normal and one abnormal pseudocholinesterase gene (heterozygous) will have blockade for 20-30 minutes whereas patients with two abnormal genes (homozygous) can have blockade for up to 4-8 hours. It is treated with continued mechanical ventilation and sedation until the muscle function comes back to normal.

Other options:

Option A- Acetylcholinesterase metabolizes acetylcholine in the synaptic space.

Options B and C- Monoamine oxidase and catechol-O-methyltransferases are the enzymes that metabolize norepinephrine.

Related Pearl: Dibucaine number

  • High dibucaine number (80) means the high quantity of normal and low quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: normal response to succinylcholine and mivacurium.
  • Low dibucaine number (<30) means the low quantity of normal and high quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: prolonged succinylcholine and mivacurium block.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

questions.text: In which of the following situations should nasal cannula be avoided?

choices.text: Requiring inspiratory oxygen flow rate of 45 L/min

questions.solution:
A nasal cannula is a low flow variable performance oxygen delivery system. It is not suited for patients requiring high FiO2 or inspiratory oxygen flow rates greater than 40 L/min for which devices like venturi mask, anaesthetic bag, air-entraining nebulizers, or high flow air oxygen systems are preferred.

Indications of a nasal cannula and other low-flow oxygen delivery systems include 

  • Minute ventilation < 8–10 L/min
  • Breathing frequencies < 20 breaths/min
  • Tidal volumes (V T ) < 0.8 L
  • Normal inspiratory flow (10–30 L/min).

questions.text: What is the oxygen delivery rate of the device shown below?
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is a non-rebreather mask. It can give up to 10-15 liters of oxygen per minute.

The non-rebreather mask is a low-flow device that can be used to deliver oxygen at higher concentrations (FiO2 80-95%). It is used in patients who are severely hypoxic but are ventilating well. It uses a reservoir bag to let the oxygen get concentrated while a one-way valve doesn't allow it to breathe in expired air.

Other examples of low-flow devices are:

  • Nasal cannula
  • Face mask
  • Face tent
  • Non-rebreather mask.

High-flow devices include:

  • Venturi mask
  • High flow nasal cannula
  • Mechanical ventilation

questions.text:
You are doing your first-year residency in anesthesia. In which of the following patients would you administer a higher amount of inhalational anesthetic?
  1. A 5-month-old child undergoing surgery.
  2. A 22-year-old man with serum sodium levels 150 mmol/L.
  3. A 50-year-old woman with BP 80/55 mmHg.
  4. A 16-year-old girl with hemoglobin< 6gm/dL.
  5. A 30-year-old woman with serum calcium levels 7 mg/dL.
questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) increases in neonates, hypernatremia (total serum sodium >145 mmol/L), and hypocalcemia (total serum calcium < 8.8 mg/dL). Thus, 1, 2, and 5 will require a higher amount of inhalational anesthetic agents.

MAC is defined as the inhaled anesthetic atmospheric pressure required to prevent movement in response to a defined noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects. MAC is unique to each inhaled anesthetic. 

It is used to express the potency of anesthetic agents. Thus, the lower the MAC, the higher the potency. 

Hypotensive patients (blood pressure < 90/60 mmHg) and patients with anemia would require a lower amount of anesthetic agents.

Effect of age on MAC: MAC is the highest at 6 months of age, after which it declines. After the age of 40, MAC reduces by ~6% per decade.

questions.text: What is the range of value of Bispectral index (BIS) for a patient who is under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The Bispectral index value range of 40-60 is seen in a patient under general anesthesia. 

The bispectral index (BIS) is an empirically derived scale that helps to monitor the depth of anesthesia and prevent intraoperative awareness. It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 to 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness.

Bispectral index value range: 

  • 100 - Awake and response to normal voice present
  • 80 - Light/moderate sedation (May respond to loud commands or mild prodding/shaking)
  • 60 - General anesthesia (Low probability of explicit recall, Unresponsive to verbal stimulus)
  • 40 - Deep hypnotic state
  • 20 - Burst suppression
  • 0 - Flatline EEG

questions.text: You are posted as a junior resident in the Emergency Medicine department, where you have to resuscitate an 11-month-old infant who is not breathing and you cannot get the pulse. According to the AHA 2020 guidelines for the pediatric basic and advanced life support, you would be correct to perform all of the following steps except:

choices.text: Use a cuffed endotracheal tube for intubating this child
Apply cricoid pressure  during endotracheal intubation
Administer the initial dose of epinephrine within 5 minutes from the start of chest compressions

questions.solution:
According to the AHA 2020 guidelines, routine use of cricoid pressure is not recommended during the endotracheal intubation of pediatric patients.

It is reasonable to choose cuffed ETTs over uncuffed ETTs for intubating infants and children. When a cuffed ETT is used, attention should be paid to tube size, position, and cuff inflation pressure (usually <20-25 cm H2O).

For infants and children with a pulse but an absent or inadequate respiratory effort, it is reasonable to give 1 breath every 2 to 3 seconds (20-30 breaths/min). For pediatric patients in any setting, it is reasonable to administer the initial dose of epinephrine within 5 minutes from the start of chest compressions.

questions.text: In which of the following devices is Murphy's eye seen?
questions.solution:
Murphy's eye is seen in the endotracheal tube (ETT).

Murphy's eye refers to the distal opening in the side wall of the ETT.

If the distal end of the lumen of the tube is blocked by secretions, Murphy's eye serves to provide an alternate route for ventilation.

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of an unresponsive patient with an absent pulse following bupivacaine administration is most likely due to bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity resulting from accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetic. The best course of management in this scenario would be administering CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation), along with a 20% intralipid injection.

Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic that is the most cardiotoxic among the local anesthetics. It depresses the rapid phase of depolarization in Purkinje fibers and ventricular muscle due to a decreased availability of fast sodium channels in cardiac membranes. This reduced rate of depolarization depresses myocardial contractility. Hence, bupivacaine is a potent cardio depressant.

Cardio-vascular effects of bupivacaine-induced toxicity are as follows:

  • Left ventricular depression
  • Atrioventricular heart block
  • Ventricular arrhythmias and ventricular fibrillation
  • Sinus bradycardia can lead to cardiac arrest

Initial management includes immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation as per the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm.

Following CPR, intralipid therapy is initiated. Its mechanism is explained by the lipid sink theory which states lipophilic drugs (bupivacaine) are absorbed into the lipid emulsion of the plasma, hence, removed from tissues affected by toxicity.

A rapid bolus of intralipid 20% IV (1.5 mL/kg) is administered without delay, followed by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min. The infusion should be given continuously for at least 10 minutes after hemodynamic stability is achieved. 

Local anesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST) can also affect the central nervous system (CNS), which is more susceptible to local anesthetic action as compared to the cardiovascular system. Dizziness, tinnitus, and disorientation are the initial symptoms. Shivering, muscular twitching, and tremors follow. Tonic-clonic seizures occur. Finally, respiratory depression can lead to respiratory arrest.

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below. 

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
The maneuver performed in the given image is jaw-thrust. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway, particularly in patients with a cervical spine injury.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. The Jaw-thrust maneuver moves the tongue anteriorly with the mandible, reducing the obstruction of the airway by the tongue. Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It can be performed in a patient with cervical injury but caution must be followed to not hyperextend the neck.

The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing as per the AHA 2020 guidelines.

Other options: 

Option A: In a head-tilt chin-lift one hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and middle finger of the opposite hand. This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat. Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury. The process is demonstrated in the GIF below:

questions.text: MAC value of an inhaled anesthetic is a measure of_____
questions.solution:
MAC (minimum alveolar concentration) value of an inhaled anesthetic is a measure of potency of the anesthetic agent.

The speed of onset and recovery is indicated by the blood gas partition coefficient.

Least potent: Nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104%. 1MAC with nitrous oxide is practically not possible and thus it is always combined with other agents.

Most potent: Methoxyflurane (MAC- 0.16%) > Trilene (MAC-0.2%), both of which are obsolete now. Among the inhaled agents in clinical use, Halothane is the most potent.

questions.text: N2O is not a suitable agent for use all of the following patients except:

choices.text: A 42 year old RTA victim who is found to have pneumocephalus on CT scan
A 27 year old female with a low pain tolerance who is very anxious about the dental procedure she is set to undergo
A 31 year old female who is set to undergo a tympanoplasty
A 39 year old male with acute intestinal obstruction and bowel distension

questions.solution:
A 27-year-old female with a low pain tolerance who is very anxious about the dental procedure she is set to undergo would be a suitable candidate for use of N2O

Cases in which nitrous oxide is contraindicated: 

  • venous or arterial air embolism
  • pneumothorax,
  • acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention,
  • intracranial air (pneumocephalus following dural closure or pneumoencephalography),
  • pulmonary air cysts,
  • intraocular air bubbles,
  • tympanic membrane grafting

Nitrous oxide is an inhalational anaesthetic agent that is used predominantly as an adjuvant during inhalational induction of general anaesthesia. 

Typical clinical uses include:

Induction - It is used as an adjuvant because of the low solubility in blood. Due to this, the rate of rise of alveolar concentration (low blood:gas partition coefficient) occurs very rapidly which makes it suitable for this purpose. It has a low potency (MAC value of 104) which makes in unsuitable for use as a sole anaesthetic agent

Maintenance - It can be used for maintenance of anaesthesia because it is cost-effective and the dose of other drugs used in combination can be lowered appropriately

Sedation - It may be used for short procedures'

 Advantages of N20:

  • It is a sweet-smelling gas that is not pungent and does not cause airway irritation
  • Very low blood: gas partition coefficient
  • Increased speed of anaesthetic onset and offset when used in combination with other agents which is called the second-gas effect
  • Analgesic and anxiolytic properties makes it ideal for induction
  • No major effects on haemodynamics
  • Low cost 

Adverse effects and disadvantages:

  • Very low potency
  • Ability to diffuse into air-filled cavities to displace nitrogen
  • Transient diffusion hypoxia  at low inspired oxygen concentrations
  • Myocardial depression, sympathetic nervous system stimulation and mildly increased pulmonary vascular resistance.
  • Inactivation of Vitamin B12 which leads to inhibition of methionine synthetase activity

 

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text:
Effective CPR includes:
  1. Respiratory rate: 20 - 24 breaths per minute
  2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min
  3. Allow complete chest recoil
  4. 5-6 cm depression
questions.solution:
The ideal rescue breath rate for adults is 10 breaths/min, while in infants and children up to puberty it is 12-20 breaths/min. As the person's age group is not specified in the question, assuming an adult, statement A is incorrect, while B, C, and D are correct.

Effective chest compression in adults:

  • Provide 100-120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • Place your arms, one over the other in the midline, on the lower 1/3rd of the patient's sternum, and lock your arms.
  • Use both arms to press the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm (2 - 2.4 inches)or more.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty:

  • The compression rate is 100 - 120/min  (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One or both palms are placed in the midline.
  • Depth of compression is 2 inches.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Effective chest compressions in infants (<1 year):

  • 100 to 120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One provider: Place two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below.
  • Two providers: Encircle the infant's torso with both hands, with both thumbs pointing cephalic, positioned 1cm below the nipples over the sternum. 
  • Depth of compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was posted for bronchoscopy under procedural sedation. After administration of anesthetic drugs, he developed chest wall rigidity and ineffective spontaneous ventilation. Attempts at manual ventilation were unsuccessful due to the non-compliant chest wall. Opioid most commonly implicated with this condition is?
questions.solution:
Chest wall rigidity and ineffective ventilation is a classic presentation of 'wooden chest syndrome'. This opioid-induced muscle rigidity is most commonly seen with the use of fentanyl and its congeners (alfentanil, sufentanil, and remifentanil).

Risk factors for wooden chest syndrome:

  • Rapid administration of a large dose of fentanyl
  • Concomitant use of nitrous oxide
  • Old age

The clinical presentation can vary from mild hoarseness to chest wall rigidity severe enough to prevent adequate bag-and-mask ventilation.

Management of wooden chest syndrome:

  • Use of short-acting neuromuscular blockade and ventilatory support
  • Reversal of the effects of fentanyl with naloxone

The rapidity of injection and the dose of fentanyl are the key determinants in the incidence and severity of wooden chest syndrome. Preliminary neurochemical and neuroanatomic data support the possibility of paradoxical activation of the Locus coeruleus with increased noradrenergic activity and selective activation of vagal motor nuclei by fentanyl.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male with a history of myocardial infarction two months back has been planned for elective cholecystectomy because of cholelithiasis. During his preoperative evaluation, he has an ejection fraction of 40%. The following image shows an assessment of his airway. He would be classified as_________

ASA PS- American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status
questions.solution:
This patient, who is about to undergo an elective cholecystectomy can be classified as ASA PS 4 with an airway assessment grade 3 as per Mallampati classification.

He has a recent history of MI two months back and severe reduction in ejection fraction (40%), which together puts the patient under Physical Status 4 as per American Society of Anaesthesiologist classification of patients.

questions.text: An ICU patient who is dependant on oxygen support requires an MRI. What material is used to build the medical gas cylinder which can be used in this scenario?

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient who is under the support of a mechanical ventilator in ICU is found to be improving and is planned to be weaned off from ventilatory support. As an anesthetist, you plan to give spontaneous breathing trials using a T-piece. All of the following is a pre-requisite for weaning off except

choices.text: Vital capacity >10 ml/ kg body weight

questions.solution:
Rapid shallow breathing index should be < 105 to wean off a patient from a mechanical ventilator.

Tidal volume is kept ideally at 4-6 ml/kg body weight. A value more than this will cause lung injury.

A patient on mechanical ventilation should be tried to wean off when he can breathe spontaneously and is hemodynamically stable with adequate arterial oxygen saturation.

Additional criteria include,

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20-30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: <10 L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index(RSBI): <105

Note: Patients with an RSBI of less than 105 can be successfully extubated. Those with an RSBI greater than 120 should retain mechanical ventilator support.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
The patient has an organized, apparently normal ECG without a pulse - i.e the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA). A pulseless electrical activity involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms, all without a pulse.

The immediate treatment for this is giving chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest until definitive therapy to the cause can be instituted.

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest because the treatment for each of them is different and PEA is likely to persist until the cause is treated.

questions.text: In a child with difficult intravenous cannulation, an emergency intraosseous infusion is made through the tibia. What is the ideal site for inserting the needle in this tibial intraosseous infusion?

choices.text: Below the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle towards the epiphyseal plate
Below the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle away from epiphyseal plate
Above the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle towards the epiphyseal plate
Above the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle away from epiphyseal plate

questions.solution:
In tibial intraosseous infusion, a needle is inserted 2–3 cm below the tibial tuberosity at a 45° angle away from the epiphyseal plate.

Intraosseous access involves placing a catheter into the marrow venous plexus and administering crystalloids, colloids, drugs and blood which leads to rapid and reliable absorption into the systemic circulation. It provides emergency access to the venous circulation in pediatric patients by way of the large medullary venous channels. The needle is directed away from the epiphyseal plate to minimize the risk of injury.

The disadvantage of this route is the risk of osteomyelitis, compartment syndrome, and bone marrow or fat embolism.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male patient is being evaluated for sweating, palpitations, and pallor that occur a few times a day. He was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and planned for surgery. Choose the incorrect statement regarding anesthesia for this patient.

choices.text: Ketamine may exacerbate the effects of his condition
Halothane can be used safely in this patient
Vecuronium is safe to use in this patient

questions.solution:
Halothane should not be used in the patient as it sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic effects of epinephrine.

Pheochromocytoma is a condition where the chromaffin tissue, most commonly in the adrenal medulla, produces excessive norepinephrine and epinephrine. 

Other anaesthetic drugs to be avoided in a pheochromocytoma patient are:

  • Succinylcholine - can cause fasciculations which lead to raised intraabdominal pressure and catecholamine release from the tumor
  • Ketamine - as it is sympathomimetic and might exacerbate the effects of adrenergic agonists
  • Anticholinergics and Pancuronium – vagal blockade leading to tachycardia
  • Atracurium – due to histamine release which may provoke catecholamine release. The safest options for these patients would be vecuronium and rocuronium

Other considerations in patients with pheochromocytoma:

  • Phenoxybenzamine, an alpha1-antagonist, which can be administered orally, is often given preoperatively to reverse the vasoconstriction. This results in a drop in arterial blood pressure and a drop in hematocrit
  • Phentolamine is used intraoperatively to control hypertensive episodes
  • A major regional block such as spinal/epidural could block sensory and sympathetic discharge in the area of the surgical field. But catecholamines released from the pheochromocytoma could still bind to receptors all over the body.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for brain death, except:
questions.solution:
All the options are criteria for brain death, except absent deep tendon reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes/ spinal cord reflexes may be present in brain death as the spinal cord function below C1 is intact.

  • Absent motor activity- No decerebrate or decorticate posturing

questions.text: A 25-year-old football player is brought to the emergency room after falling on the field during a match. His X-ray shows the findings below. Which of the following peripheral blocks is indicated to restore the normal anatomy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of shoulder dislocation as seen on the X-ray. Interscalene block provides surgical anaesthesia for procedures of the shoulder and upper arm.

Interscalene nerve block is performed between the anterior and middle scalene muscles in the inter-scalene groove at the level of C6, where the brachial plexus emerges. It provides an adequate block of the superior and middle trunks of the brachial plexus. The ulnar nerve (C8, T1) from the inferior trunk may be missed. Hence, this block is not used for procedures of the forearm and hand.

The most common complication of inter-scalene block seen in 100% of patients is diaphragmatic hemiparesis due to ipsilateral phrenic nerve blockade. This can result in dyspnea, hypoxia, and hypercapnia, especially if the patient has compromised lung function or preexisting contralateral phrenic nerve paralysis.

Other complications of inter-scalene block are:

  • Horners syndrome – ptosis, myosis, anhydrosis. Due to the involvement of the sympathetic nerves in the cervicothoracic ganglion. (loss of ciliospinal reflex)
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • Vagus nerve involvement
  • Pneumothorax (stratosphere sign on ultrasound of the chest)
  • Bezold Jarisch reflex (hypotension, bradycardia and coronary vasodilation)
  • Accidental vertebral artery injection (immediate seizure is seen)
  • Accidental spinal or epidural injection

questions.text: Which of the following investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications?
questions.solution:
Among the given investigations, dobutamine stress echocardiography provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications.

Preoperative cardiac stress testing can help identify the presence and severity of preexisting CAD. The prognostic performance of these tests is better assessed based on positive and negative likelihood ratios. Among all the given options, dobutamine stress echocardiography has the maximum positive likelihood ratio and hence provides the most accurate prognostic information.

Even though coronary angiography is considered the gold standard, it may not absolutely risk-stratify patients because many perioperative cardiac events may be related to noncritical coronary lesions.

questions.text: As an anesthesia consultant, you're planning to insert a central venous line for a patient requiring inotropes and parenteral nutrition for a prolonged period. Which of the following veins will you choose so as to have reduced long-term complications?
questions.solution:
Among the given options subclavian is the best vein for long-term cannulation.

The usual complications of prolonged cannulations include line infection, sepsis, air or thrombus embolism, arrhythmias, hematoma, hemothorax, and thrombosis.

As compared to cannulation of other veins, subclavian vein cannulation has a reduced risk of complications due to prolonged cannulations. It is, however, associated with a maximum risk of pneumothorax.

Other options:

Option B- The internal jugular vein on the right side is better than the left side. Left-sided insertion has an increased risk of pleural effusion and chylothorax.

Option C- The external jugular vein is less preferred because it enters at an acute angle into chest veins, hence there are decreased chances of easy access.

Option D- Femoral veins are less preferred for long-term usage because they are associated with frequent line-related sepsis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was undergoing a craniotomy procedure for a posterior cranial fossa tumor in a sitting position. Intraoperatively, there was a sudden drastic drop in EtCO2 to 8 mmHg and blood pressure dropped to 80/50 mmHg. A venous air embolism was suspected. What is the immediate next step of management?

choices.text: Compress jugular vein to limit air entry to chest circulation
Administer nitrous oxide to eliminate the emboli
Stop 100% oxygen administration to prevent further air embolism

questions.solution:
In this given scenario of venous air embolism (VAE), the immediate next step of management is to compress the jugular vein to limit air entry to chest circulation.

The goal of treatment in VAE is to prevent further air entry, treat the intravascular air and hemodynamic support.

  • The first immediate step is to notify the surgeon to cover the surgical field with a saline-soaked dressing and tilt the table to prevent further air entry. In surgeries done in a sitting position, the jugular venous compression can restrict air entry into chest circulation.
  • Improve patient oxygenation by administration of 100% oxygen. It also reduces embolus volume by eliminating nitrogen. Nitrous oxide should be discontinued even after minor embolic events to prevent the air from reaching left-sided circulation.
  • Air entry to the right side of the heart may be relieved by a partial left lateral decubitus position. Aspiration of air from the right atrium can be tried by the use of a Bunegin-Albin multi-orifice catheter.
  • Maintain optimum fluid status and stabilize the patient with inotropes or pressors if needed.
  • In case of massive VAE with cardiac decompensation, initiate rapid cardiopulmonary resuscitation with chest compression.
  • To decrease the severity of the disease, initiate anticoagulation therapy with heparin. The usage of steroids is controversial as steroids do not have any effect on cytotoxic brain edema resulting from air embolism.

VAE refers to the entrapment of exogenously delivered gas or air into the venous vasculature resulting in systemic effects. It may occur during surgeries like sitting neurological procedures (posterior cranial fossa surgeries), obstetrics, and orthopedic surgeries. Other causes include mechanical insufflation during laparoscopic surgeries, iatrogenic air entry during venous catheterization and dysbarism. 

VAE should be considered when unexplained hypotension or a sudden fall in end-tidal CO2 level occurs intraoperatively in high-risk cases. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the most sensitive device for detecting intracardiac air embolus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with compensated cirrhosis is being posted for a liver transplantation. As an anesthetist on duty, which of the following induction agents will you use?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane and isoflurane are commonly used for induction in patients with liver disease.

Hepatic arterial blood flow is reduced in cirrhosis. Sevoflurane and isoflurane are known to maintain hepatic blood flow and improve oxygen delivery to the liver.

Sevoflurane due to its nonpungency and rapid onset makes it an excellent choice for smooth and rapid inhalation inductions in pediatric and adult patients.

Compound A is the nephrotoxic end product formed by the interaction of sevoflurane with CO2-absorbent soda lime. Accumulation of this product occurs on long-duration anesthesia, high sevoflurane concentrations, and dry barium hydroxide absorbent.

Other options-

Option (A): Methoxyflurane is a hepatotoxic and highly nephrotoxic drug. Its use gradually declined after the 1970s. 

Option (B): Thiopentone, also known as thiopental, is a barbiturate that is excreted primarily via the liver. Hence, it would lead to toxicity is used in patients with liver disease.

Option (D): Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic agent that accumulates in the liver and undergoes rapid metabolism. It is also known to cause hepatotoxicity which presents as an elevation in liver enzymes. These two reasons make ketamine unsuitable for use in patients with liver disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the airway adjunct shown in the image given below?

choices.text: It is used only in unconscious patients
Prevents falling back of tongue post-extubation
Prevents tongue bite during seizure activity
Can be used in patients with central facial fracture

questions.solution:
The image shows nasopharyngeal airway and its insertion. The true statement is that it is used to prevent falling back of tongue post-extubation especially in obese patients.

Nasopharyngeal airways are less stimulating than oropharyngeal airways as it bypasses the gag reflex. Thus, it can be used in conscious patients as well.

It does not prevent tongue bite unlike the oropharyngeal airway which has a bite block. It can prevent falling back of the tongue in patients with seizures.

It is contraindicated in

  • Basilar skull fractures, central facial fractures, CSF rhinorrhea - risk of meningitis
  • Patients on anticoagulants, coagulopathies, epistaxis - risk of bleeding
  • Relatively contraindicated in pregnancy (increased vascularity leading to bleeding), deformity of the nose.

questions.text:
Match the following gas cylinders with their respective pin indices.
  1. 2, 5
  2. 7
  3. 3, 5
  4. 1, 5
  5. No pin index
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-A, 2-E, 3-B, 4-C.

Pin Index Safety System (PISS) is a unique configuration of holes and pins which match precisely to eliminate the connection of a wrong cylinder to equipment, thus preventing delivery of wrong gas to a patient. It incorporates two holes in specific positions on the cylinder valve below the outlet port. The cylinder can only be connected to a pressure regulator or yolk, with the corresponding matching pair of pins.

Oxygen cylinders are black cylinders with white shoulders. The pin index of the oxygen cylinder is 2,5. The maximum pressure in the oxygen cylinder is around 2000 psi. The critical temperature of oxygen is -119 ºC, hence it is present in the gaseous form at room temperature.

Helium is stored in brown-colored cylinders and has no pin index. Helium-oxygen mixture, together known as heliox, is used to improve gaseous exchange in acute exacerbation of asthma and COPD. The helium-oxygen mixture in 79%-21% ratio is sometimes used in anesthetic practice to provide relief from upper airway obstructions due to subglottic edema, foreign bodies, and tracheal tumors. It is only a temporary measure that is used until definitive care is provided. 

The cylinder with a blue body and white shoulder is the Entonox cylinder. Its PIN index is 7. Entonox is 50:50 mixture of nitrous oxide and oxygen, popularly used as labor analgesia in maternity suites.

Blue cylinders are used to store nitrous oxide. The pin index of these cylinders is 3, 5.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who underwent surgery for appendicitis was given a high dose of opioids postoperatively to relieve the pain. But within a few hours,  a fall in SpO2 and respiratory rate were noted. Which of the following drugs has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid-induced respiratory depression and naloxone has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient.

Opioid-induced respiratory depression is mediated by the action on µ receptors in the brainstem respiratory centers. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist, which can reverse the respiratory depression induced by opioids.

Respiratory depression can be prolonged when opioids are taken with other CNS depressant substances like alcohol, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, inhalational anesthetics, and other sedative-hypnotics.

However, droperidol, scopolamine, and clonidine do not increase the respiratory depressant effects of fentanyl or other opioids.

questions.text: Gas from which of the following cylinders can be used in patients with acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma along with oxygen?
questions.solution:
The gas in the cylinder with a brown shoulder and body is helium. Helium along with oxygen, together known as heliox can be used in the treatment of acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma as they decrease the work of breathing. Heliox can be used to deliver inhaled 𝛃2 agonists in patients with severe critical asthma.

Principle:

  • When the flow across the bronchus is laminar, the flow rate increases as the gas viscosity decreases.
  • In airway obstructing conditions, where there is turbulent flow, the flow rate decreases as the gas density increases. Hence helium, having low density is added with oxygen to increase the flow rate. It decreases the resistance in the airways and improves ventilation and gas exchange.

The other options represent general anaesthetics and are not useful in treating bronchial asthma.

  • Violet: Ethylene
  • Blue: N2O
  • Orange: Cyclopropane

questions.text: The image shown below is the technique of insertion of?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of insertion of laryngeal mask airway.

Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that is positioned in the hypopharynx.

Classic Laryngeal Mask Airway

Supraglottic airway devices are used with both spontaneously and ventilated patients during anesthesia.

LMA has advantages of being used in many settings, including the operating room (alternate route of ventilation), the emergency department (difficult intubation), and out-of-hospital care (paramedics).

This is because it is easy to use, quick to place even for the inexperienced provider and has a very high success rate.

The technique of insertion:

  • The deflated cuff of LMA is lubricated and inserted blindly into the hypopharynx so that, once inflated, the cuff forms a low-pressure seal around the entrance to the larynx.
  • Correct placement of the tube is confirmed by giving gentle positive pressure ventilation while checking for chest rise and ETCO2 using capnography.

 

Note:

Oropharyngeal airway: inserted in the patient’s mouth with concavity towards hard palate. As the airway is inserted it is rotated 180 degrees (concavity towards the tongue) until the flange comes to rest on the patient’s lips. 

 

Nasopharyngeal airway: inserted through the nostril (after lubrication) along the natural curvature of the floor of the nasal cavity with the bevel pointing towards the septum. Once the device is inserted the flange should rest on the nostril opening.

Endotracheal tube: inserted infraglottically after visualising the vocal cords with direct laryngoscopy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient, who was diagnosed with severe ARDS  was shifted to the intensive care unit and was put on mechanical ventilation with high PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure). This ventilatory setting results in all of the following nonpulmonary effects  except
questions.solution:
Mechanical ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) setting results in all the above effects except decrease in Antidiuretic hormone level.

Positive end-expiratory pressure(PEEP)

PEEP is a mode of therapy used in conjunction with mechanical ventilation. Application of positive pressure during expiration as an adjunct to a mechanically ventilated breath is referred to as PEEP.

The principal mechanism of action appears to be the expansion of partially collapsed alveoli.

Pulmonary effects: 

  • In patients with decreased lung volume, appropriate levels of PEEP will increase FRC and tidal ventilation and thereby improving lung compliance.
  • It also helps in correcting ventilation/perfusion mismatch and aid in improving arterial oxygenation.

Nonpulmonary effects:

  • Urinary output decreases
  • Glomerular filtration decreases.
  • Circulating levels of antidiuretic hormone and angiotensin are usually elevated.
  • Central venous pressure increases
  • Progressive reductions in cardiac output
  • Decrease in both renal and hepatic blood flow.
  • Decreased free water clearance

questions.text: You are a resident posted in the medicine ward. A patient who has been previously diagnosed with epilepsy has an episode of seizures and becomes unconscious. You immediately call a code. The patient is unresponsive and chest rise is not appreciable but you can feel a pulse. You suspect that this is due to falling back of the tongue and decide to secure the airway using the device shown. What landmarks would you use before selecting the appropriate size?

choices.text: Incisor teeth and tragus of the ear
Corner of mouth and angle of mandible
Tip of nose and angle of mandible
Ala of nose and angle of mandible

questions.solution:
The image shows oropharyngeal airway or Guedel airway of various sizes. The landmarks used for measuring the appropriate size of this device are the corner of the mouth and the angle of the mandible or tragus.

An oropharyngeal airway is an airway adjunct which keeps the tongue from falling back onto the posterior pharynx.

It is essential to choose the correct size since inappropriately sized ones may aggravate airway obstruction. 

These airways should not be used in conscious patients as they may come into contact with the epiglottis and base of tongue. This can cause coughing, retching or laryngospasm if the pharyngeal and laryngeal reflexes are not blunted with local anaesthetic. 

Note: Nasopharyngeal airway size is chosen by measuring the distance between the tip of the nose and tragus of the ear. These airways, when well lubricated and inserted with proper technique, can be used in conscious patients to secure an airway.

questions.text: A 36-year-old housewife is scheduled for an excision biopsy of a breast lump under general anaesthesia. The procedure is planned on an outpatient basis. Which is the intravenous induction agent of choice for her?
questions.solution:
The intravenous induction agent of choice for ambulatory anesthesia is propofol.

Propofol has a rapid onset of action and a faster recovery. This makes it an ideal induction agent for outpatient/ambulatory/day care anesthesia.

Besides, propofol has antiemetic properties which help reduce post-operative nausea and vomiting.
